Prompt:
You will receive a transcript of a debate between two participants (P1, P2).
Identify and label the arguments in the final turn's statement (referred to as CURRENT).
CURRENT may include an “argument” (a main point or thesis) and several sentences or premises (“reasons”).
First, extract each argument from CURRENT.
- Arguments must be complete sentences (begin with a capital letter and end with punctuation such as “.”, “?”, “!”, etc.) exactly as they appear in the text.
- Not all parts of CURRENT are necessarily arguments or reasons (e.g., “hi, I wish to discuss the elections” is not).
- Arguments can exist without supporting reasons (e.g., "I don't believe climate change is bad").
- They may also be enthymemes, implicitly referring to other parts of the dialogue (e.g., "I disagree") or simply stating a position (e.g., "I wish to talk about tech's D&I policies and how they haven't moved the needle for inclusion").
- Simple affirmations or denials (e.g., "Yes.", "No.") should be included as part of the argument if they directly respond to a thesis or premise.
- If no arguments are present, write N/A.
After extracting the arguments, label them based on the following criteria.
C-0: Are there reasons provided to support the thesis?
- 2 if there are reasons to support the thesis.
- 1 if there are some reasons, but they are difficult to link.
- 0 if it is a thesis without supporting reasons.
InitialPrompt:
You will be given a transcript of two participants (P1, P2) having a debate.
Extract and label the arguments for the last turn's statement (denoted by CURRENT) and label them.
This means that CURRENT may be comprised of an “argument” (a thesis, the point someone is making) and multiple sentences or premises (“reasons”).
First extract every argument from CURRENT.
- Arguments must be a complete sentence (start with a capital letter and end in “.”, “?”, “!”, etc) verbatim from the text.
- Not all parts of CURRENT need to be arguments or reasons (for example “hi, I wish to discuss the elections” is neither).
- Arguments can also lack supporting reasons ("I don't believe climate change is bad")
- They also may be enthymemes, and implicitly refer to other parts of the dialogue ("I disagree"); or simply state a position ("I wish to talk about tech's D&I policies and how they haven't moved the needle for inclusion").
- If there are no arguments, write N/A.
After extracting the arguments, label them according to the criteria below.
C-0: Are there reasons provided to support the thesis?
- 2 if there are reasons to support the thesis.
- 1 if there are some reasons, but it is hard to link them.
- 0 if it is a thesis without supporting reasons.

You will be given a transcript of a debate between two participants (P1, P2). Your task is to identify and label the arguments in the final turn's statement (referred to as CURRENT). CURRENT may contain an “argument” (a main point or thesis) and several sentences or premises (“reasons”).

First, extract each argument from CURRENT.
- Arguments must be complete sentences (starting with a capital letter and ending with punctuation such as “.”, “?”, “!”, etc.) exactly as they appear in the text.
- Not all parts of CURRENT are necessarily arguments or reasons (e.g., “hi, I wish to discuss the elections” is not).
- Arguments can exist without supporting reasons (e.g., "I don't believe climate change is bad").
- They may also be enthymemes, implicitly referring to other parts of the dialogue (e.g., "I disagree") or simply stating a position (e.g., "I wish to talk about tech's D&I policies and how they haven't moved the needle for inclusion").
- Simple affirmations or denials (e.g., "Yes.", "No.") should be included as part of the argument if they directly respond to a thesis or premise.
- If no arguments are present, write N/A.

After extracting the arguments, label them based on the following criteria.
C-0: Are there reasons provided to support the thesis?
- 2 if there are reasons to support the thesis.
- 1 if there are some reasons, but they are difficult to link.
- 0 if it is a thesis without supporting reasons.

Note: Pay special attention to arguments that are implicit or rely heavily on the context of the previous dialogue. Ensure that these are identified and labeled correctly.

You will receive a transcript of a debate between two participants (P1, P2). Your task is to identify and label the arguments in the final turn's statement (referred to as CURRENT). CURRENT may contain an “argument” (a main point or thesis) and several sentences or premises (“reasons”).

First, extract each argument from CURRENT.
- Arguments must be complete sentences (starting with a capital letter and ending with punctuation such as “.”, “?”, “!”, etc.) exactly as they appear in the text.

- Arguments can exist without supporting reasons (e.g., "I don't believe climate change is bad").
- They may also be enthymemes, implicitly referring to other parts of the dialogue (e.g., "I disagree") or simply stating a position (e.g., "I wish to talk about tech's D&I policies and how they haven't moved the needle for inclusion").
- Simple affirmations or denials (e.g., "Yes.", "No.") should be included as part of the argument if they directly respond to a thesis or premise.
- Follow-up questions or clarifications that are part of the dialogue but not necessarily arguments should not be extracted as arguments (e.g., "But why do you think that AI needs human oversight and accountability? Can't AI have self-oversight and accountability?").

After extracting the arguments, label them based on the following criteria.

- 0 if it is a thesis without supporting reasons.

Output:

You will be provided with a transcript of a debate between two participants (P1, P2).
Identify and label the arguments in the final turn's statement (referred to as CURRENT).
CURRENT may consist of an “argument” (the main point being made) and several sentences or premises (“reasons”).
First, extract each argument from CURRENT.
- Arguments must be complete sentences (begin with a capital letter and end with punctuation such as “.”, “?”, “!”, etc) exactly as they appear in the text.
- Not all parts of CURRENT are necessarily arguments or reasons (e.g., “hi, I wish to discuss the elections” is neither).
- Arguments can exist without supporting reasons ("I don't believe climate change is bad").
- They may also be enthymemes, implicitly referring to other parts of the dialogue ("I disagree"), or simply stating a position ("I wish to talk about tech's D&I policies and how they haven't moved the needle for inclusion").
- If there are no arguments, write N/A.
After extracting the arguments, label them based on the following criteria.
C-0: Are there reasons provided to support the thesis?
- 2 if there are clear and direct reasons supporting the thesis within CURRENT.
- 1 if there are some reasons, but it is difficult to directly link them to the thesis within CURRENT.
- 0 if it is a thesis without supporting reasons within CURRENT.

You will receive a transcript of a debate between two participants (P1, P2). Your task is to identify and label the arguments in the final turn's statement (referred to as CURRENT). CURRENT may include an “argument” (the main point being made) and several sentences or premises (“reasons”).

First, extract each argument from CURRENT.
- Arguments must be complete sentences (starting with a capital letter and ending with punctuation such as “.”, “?”, “!”, etc) exactly as they appear in the text.
- Not all parts of CURRENT are necessarily arguments or reasons (e.g., “hello, I want to talk about the elections” is neither).
- Arguments can exist without supporting reasons ("I don't think climate change is harmful").
- They may also be enthymemes, implicitly referring to other parts of the dialogue ("I disagree"), or simply stating a position ("I want to discuss tech's D&I policies and their lack of impact on inclusion").
- If there are no arguments, write N/A.

After extracting the arguments, label them based on the following criteria.
C-0: Are there reasons provided to support the thesis?
- 2 if there are clear and direct reasons supporting the thesis within CURRENT.
- 1 if there are some reasons, but it is difficult to directly link them to the thesis within CURRENT.
- 0 if it is a thesis without supporting reasons within CURRENT.

Consider the broader context of the dialogue to accurately identify and label arguments. Ensure that the arguments are not taken out of context and are evaluated within the framework of the ongoing debate.

You will be given a transcript of a debate between two participants (P1, P2). Your task is to identify and label the arguments in the final turn's statement (referred to as CURRENT). CURRENT may contain an “argument” (the main point being made) and several sentences or premises (“reasons”).

First, extract each argument from CURRENT.
- Arguments must be complete sentences (beginning with a capital letter and ending with punctuation such as “.”, “?”, “!”, etc) exactly as they appear in the text.
- Not all parts of CURRENT are necessarily arguments or reasons (e.g., “hello, I want to talk about the elections” is neither).
- Arguments can exist without supporting reasons ("I don't think climate change is harmful").
- They may also be enthymemes, implicitly referring to other parts of the dialogue ("I disagree"), or simply stating a position ("I want to discuss tech's D&I policies and their lack of impact on inclusion").

After extracting the arguments, label them based on the following criteria.
C-0: Are there reasons provided to support the thesis?
- 2 if there are clear and direct reasons supporting the thesis within CURRENT.
- 1 if there are some reasons, but it is difficult to directly link them to the thesis within CURRENT.
- 0 if it is a thesis without supporting reasons within CURRENT.

Consider the broader context of the dialogue to accurately identify and label arguments. Ensure that the arguments are not taken out of context and are evaluated within the framework of the ongoing debate.

Note: Statements of differing opinions or acknowledgments of different perspectives (e.g., "Respectfully, we have different perspectives on this matter.") are not considered arguments.
